bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Paul L. Tate, August 19, 1952

div1.p: Truby reports on his health and comments on attempts to have Ames included as a member of the Reed yellow fever board, which Truby insists is not historically accurate. He notes that Hench is still working for the preservation of Building No. 1 at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Paul L. Tate, August 19, 1952
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18, CALIFORNIA
August 19, 1952.
Mr. Paul L. Tate
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3, Calif.
Dear Tate:
div1.p:
Your letter of June 12 is among those awaiting an
answer from me. I have made slow but continuous progress
since you last heard from me. My walking is very slow
but is getting there. I still have not got strength to
walk with safety alone but I can see progress almost
daily. Quite remarkable for an old man, I think.

(I read with interest what you had to say about Dr. Brumby's)
(efforts to construe Ames' duty at Camp Lazear as being)
(a member of the Reed Board. Of course, that would not)
(hold water as I wrote to Dr. Brumby two or three years)
(ago. It was I who suggested to him that the only thing)
(I knew of to honor Ames was to have his Tulane University)
(friends erect a memorial to his honor in New Orleans.)
(I am glad that Dr. Brumby is trying to get action along)
(those lines. Ames deserved it but he was definitely not)
(entitled to membership as Dr. Brumby is trying to prove.)

I am still at the Letterman and I am talking Physio-
therapy exercises which are pretty hard for an old fellow.
However, I have managed to do them and the results, while
slow, are extremely good. I think that I will soon be
able to go home and come here for the PT work.

I have just had a letter from Dr. Hench. He is actively
trying to get the Cuban people to erect a memorial at
Camp Lazear which will protect the little building that
still remains there and which will not last much longer
unless protected from the elements. Cubans persist in
trying to call it a memorial to Finlay but Dr. Hench
objects to that as of course he should.

I am glad to see that you are holding up so well and I
hope that some time in the near future we may be able to
get together for a brief meeting.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Albert E. Truby My pen is on strike
Underline named 'Ames deserved it, is mine
Ta
